physDesc.p: Three pages typewritten in black ink. Archival notes read "Aldington" in pencil at the top of the first page. Unsigned.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

body.p: Our half-yearly statement has come in, showing the sales of our two volumes of Imagist Poets up to February 1st, from which you will see that we made $167.66. The $1.50 refers to a copy which was bound especially for a subscriber and which they charged me for on the last bill by accident. Yours and Richard’s shares, therefore, are each $27.94. Besides which there is $10.00 which "The Seven Arts" paid him for the poems "On the March" and "Leave Taking", and $5.00 from Brown on that original contract. I have added all this together in one draft for 16+16+4, which I enclose. Brown now has only $5.00 more to pay on that contract. I think in a former letter I told you that he had nothing more to pay, but I misunderstood it. I have since looked up the receipts, and found there is still $5.00 more due.

To my great distress James Oppenheim found that he could not publish "On the March" and "Leave Taking" in time for them to appear in our Anthology, and I thought it was more important for Richard to keep them in "The Seven Arts", partly because of getting more money for them, and partly because it is well to appear in different places. As I have so few of Richard’s things to choose from, and no time to do it in, the manuscript being already at the printers, I had no time to communicate with you, I substituted "Dawn" and "Images" for the poems left out. I hope this will meet with your approval. At any rate, I did what I thought would be the best thing.

I am correcting the proofs of the book today. You will be glad to know that our first volume is in the third edition, and our second volume is in the second edition, and that Constable sent for more sheets of the first volume no longer ago than last month, showing that it is still selling in England. I think that the renewed interest that the press in your country is showing in us is a very encouraging thing. Did you see poor Mr. Bourdillon’s letter in The Times? How the stand-patters do fight and how surely they are being pushed aside!

I got your letter saying that you had no anecdote. I had already taken the liberty of writing to your mother for certain data such as where you were born, where you were educated, etc. She replied that you were so reticent yourself that she could give me the barest details, but I have done the best I can, and I hope you will like book when it comes out.

Now I want a photograph for the volume. It is to be like my "Six French Poets" with photographs and signatures of each of the poets. I have a little photograph of you that you sent me last summer, but, in one of his letters to me, Richard said that you were sending me an "Art" photograph of yourself, but this has never come. Now I am a very selfish person, and I do not want to sacrifice this one photograph that I have to the lithographers because they invariably dirty and generally spoil everything that they touch. Not only do I want this photograph, but Mr. Braithwaite wants it for the Boston Transcript, and he wants it P.D.Q., for he wants to put in a review of you. Therefore, will you please send it by return mail. Even return mail will be dreadfully slow.

I enclose a very nice little mention of your book from "The Outlook". Really that book of yours was a perfect gem. I don’t know anything that gave me a greater pleasure than minutely studying your work for my lecture. It taught me a great many thing. Your perfection in your own medium is something to make every poet proud for you and despairing for himself.

While I was in New York, I had a very interesting time with Mr. Patterson of the Department of English of Columbia University, who has written a book on prose rhythm. He announced, in his book, that vers libre was only prose. I met him one afternoon and told him that I thought he was mistaken, and on that account he invited me to his laboratory where for an hour and a half I read your "Oread" into a sound machine, with the result that he has written me that he is now willing to admit what he was not willing to admit before, that the cadences of vers libre are not the cadences of prose. He was very sad when I left New York, for it is hard for him to work without me, as he knows very little about the aesthetic side of the free forms; but I think, through correspondence, and through seeing him occasionally, we may be able to make some interesting experiments, which will end by proving conclusively to the doubters that vers libre is by no means the chopped prose they think. At any rate it is a very interesting experiment.
I have not time to write any more now, as I am starting out on a lecture tour in the West and things are pressing.
Send the photograph instanter, and please send your full signature on a separate piece of paper so that I can reproduce it beneath the photograph for the book.
